content: I am a current student at UCSB studying Mathematical Science and Statistical Science with a concentration in Probability and Statistics.

summary:
A color palette creator made with React + Redux that allows you to peruse a gallery of colors based on your settings selection. Future features hope to add machine-learning generated palettes, exporting palettes for offline reference, and palette sharing! (Still a work in progress!)

[Code available here!](https://github.com/eduardoescoto/colors)

summary:
A simulator of the Strong Law of Large numbers made with React + Redux. Simulates infinite random trials of random events to illustrate the effect of the LOLNS. 

[Code available here!](https://github.com/eduardoescoto/LawOfLargeNumbersSimulator)

summary:
My LaTeX code for both my Resumes and Cover Letter. Complete with an automatic build script, as well as both 
the Resume and Cover Letter code being completely templated. All that needs to be done is have the variables changed and the information filled and they will automatically be formatted as shown!

[Code available here!](https://github.com/eduardoescoto/resume-and-coverletter)

content:
This project scrapes the hidden E-sports API that Riot uses internally for their player statistics in their League of Legends Championship series. This is written in Python and runs with a Shell script for housekeeping. It takes all of the interesting data and outputs it into neat and tidy JSON files that contain the data by event, and by player!
Code available here!
summary:
A data mining project that scrapes data from Riot's hidden LOL-Esports-Api, and aggregates the most important player data available into neat json files.

[Code available here!](https://github.com/eduardoescoto/LoLEsportsTournamentStatsScraper)
title: ðŸ‘¾ LOL E-sports Data Scraper ðŸ‘¾

A twitter bot written in node.js that randomly generates pretty pastels and tweets it along with a name, and all of its correspoding color information.

summary:
Jupyter Notebooks I worked on in my Stochastic Systems class at UCSB. The Topics range from Simulating Probability Distributions, Monte Carlo Simulations, to simulating Markov Chains and finding their stationary distributions. These notebooks illustrate core concepts in Stochastic Systems through interactive notebooks!

[Code available here!](https://github.com/eduardoescoto/Stochastic-Systems-Notebooks)
title: ðŸ“ˆ Stochastic Processes Notebooks ðŸ“ˆ

summary:
A set of regression analyses on R core datasets for my Linear Regression class. These examples showcase the power of Rmarkdown, and Tidyverse packages in generating beautiful articles in statistical analysis.

[Code available here!](https://github.com/eduardoescoto/PSTAT126_Homework_5)
